subsections.heading: 1.1 Purpose
content: This Business User Document describes the requirements for standardizing and automating the vendor creation process within the organization. It aims to ensure that vendor master data is captured accurately, approved efficiently, and made available in downstream systems in a timely and compliant manner.

subsections.heading: 1.2 Audience
content: The primary audience of this document includes business owners for procurement and finance, business analysts, project managers, solution architects, developers, and key end-users involved in vendor onboarding and maintenance. It may also be referenced by internal audit, compliance, and operations teams to validate that the implemented process aligns with policy and regulatory requirements.

subsections.heading: 2.1 Background
content: Currently, vendor creation is handled through a mix of manual forms, email-based approvals, and direct entries into the ERP/procurement system, leading to inconsistent data quality, limited visibility, and longer cycle times. The absence of a standardized workflow and controls increase the risk of duplicate vendors, incomplete documentation, and non-compliance with internal and external regulations.

subsections.heading: 2.2 Objectives
content: The project aims to design and implement a controlled, workflow-driven vendor creation process that enforces mandatory data fields, documentation checks, and role-based approvals. It also seeks to improve transparency and auditability through clear status tracking, standardized communications, and integration with the organization’s master data and finance systems.

subsections.heading: 3.1 In Scope
content: Capture and validation of vendor master data through a standardized vendor creation form (internal and external-facing).
Workflow for vendor request initiation, review, and approval, and compliance as applicable.
Storage and verification of mandatory supporting documents (e.g., tax, banking, registration, and compliance certificates).
Creation and update of vendor records in the target ERP/procurement system, including basic integration or interface design.
Basic reporting and dashboards for tracking vendor requests, status and turnaround times.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Out of Scope
content: Changes to core ERP configuration.
Advanced vendor performance management, risk scoring, and contract lifecycle management functionalities.
Decommissioning or redesign of unrelated procurement processes (e.g., purchase requisition, purchase order, or invoicing flows).
Implementation of third-party systems.

subsections.heading: 4.3 Initiation Methods
content: The process will be initiated by the initiator by logging into the system and clicking on the create option in the dashboard.
This process can be initiated by any user in the system. The user should be active in the Pidilite HRMS system. This data will be maintained in the Manch EDV system.
Note – Pidilite to share the format and data for maintaining access with the integration API.

Note – If there is any dependent dropdown, then it should be clear when the parent dropdown values are changed.
Note – If based on dropdown values, fields are visible, invisible, mandatory, or non-mandatory, then respective fields should be clear when dropdown values are changed.

Note – If the user is copying any values to another FFD and the original field is getting cleared, then copy values should also be cleared. E.g. In this process, when GST is uploaded, the GST address is copied into the address detail panel. If the GST address is getting clear, then the address details should also get clear.

subsections.heading: 4.5 Process Details
content: Below are the details of each step of the process.

subsections.heading: 4.5.1 Initiator Behaviour
content: Login: The Pidilite team logs in to the Manch application using the provided credentials. The following basic details are shown to the user for each transaction created.
Transaction ID
Company Name – Title (Copy the company name FFD Data into Title)
Process Name
Vendor Code – Attribute 1 (Copt the vendor code FFD Data into Attribute 1)
Create By – Show the created by email id
Created Date
Status – Display the external status with next approver and rejection details (when applicable)
Initiation: The user will click on the create option and select the vendor creation process.
Form will open with the below details of initiator. Initiator will be able to view only Basic details panel and fields as mentioned below. All the fields will be having common logic with them.
Once the Initiator enters the details and clicks on submit. The system will perform the validation and send the details to the vendor for them to take action.

subsections.heading: 4.5.2 Vendor Behaviour
content: Email Notification: An email containing a link is sent to the Vendor’s email address. Vendor will click on the email link and this will open a smart UI screen into  default browser.
Email Template:

Email Authentication: Once the link is open, system will ask the to enter OTP, and after successful verification, the Manch platform opens the link. Vendor will click on the enter detail option for viewing and entering the information.

Form level information: Vendor will be able to view the below mentioned fields for them to view and enter the details. This form will have to common logic along with specific vendor level behaviour logic.
Documents logic :
Based on the Vendor Type chosen, the KYC documents are conditionally mandatory and non-mandatory as follows
If the document is mentioned as not required, then the system should apply the delete the document rule conditionally and vice versa.
All the documents should get copied in the respective supporting document by applying the copy to document storage ID rule against each document upload FFD.
Once the Vendor enters the details and clicks on submit. The system will perform the validation and send the details to the approvers for them to take action.

subsections.heading: 4.5.3 Approver Behaviour
content: Below are the common points for all the approvers.

Assignment to Approver(s): Once all the mandatory fields are entered, validated, and the request is submitted by the Vendor, the system automatically assigns the request to the appropriate approver based on the approver logic defined.
Note: Pidilite team to provide the approver derivation logic.
Approver will get an email notification. Similarly, approval and rejection criteria can also be defined, if there are a preset number of rejection reasons, those can be shown as a dropdown.
Approver access: Approvers have two methods to access the transaction, review and act on requests as mentioned below -
Email Notification:
The Manch system sends an email notification to the approver with a link to review the request.
Manch System Login:
The approver can log in to the Manch system, navigate to the "Pending Requests" section, and review the details.
Approver Behaviour: Based on all the information available to approver , they can approve or reject or send back.
If approver rejects, transaction will be in rejection status and no further actions are allowed in the request.
If approver send back, transaction will be assigned back to requestor and requestor can view the comment and update the required data.
Once requestor re-submits, transaction will follow all the steps of the workflow.
Below is the default email notification content that will be sent to the approver.

subsections.heading: 4.5.3.1 Approver Flow
content: Approver flow defines the sequence of roles that must review and approve a vendor request for India and Non-India entities.
Approver flow – India
For India, the workflow will consist of six sequential approval levels:
Pending with Requestor – Initial review and confirmation by the requestor.
Pending with Vertical Head – Review and approval by the relevant business/vertical head.
Pending with Functional Head – Review and approval by the applicable functional head (e.g., Finance, Operations).
Pending with Accounts Team – Validation of accounting and finance-related information.
Pending with Auditor – Compliance and audit validation as required.

Pending with MDC Team – Final review by the MDC team. The MDC team can add ad hoc approvers as needed, up to a maximum of five parallel approvers. All ad hoc approvers must record their decisions, after which the request returns to the MDC approver, who then takes the final action in line with the defined common behaviour.
Approver flow – Non-India
For Non-India, the workflow will consist of four sequential approval levels:
Pending with Requestor – Initial review and confirmation by the requestor. It is a contributor.
Pending with Country Head – Review and approval by the respective country head.
Pending with Auditor – Compliance and audit validation as required.

Pending with MDC Team – Final review by the MDC team. The MDC team can add ad hoc approvers as needed, up to a maximum of five parallel approvers. All ad hoc approvers must record their decisions, after which the request returns to the MDC approver, who then takes the final action in line with the defined common behaviour.

subsections.heading: 4.5.3.2 Specific Approver Behaviour for Contributors
content: Pending with Requestor Specific Behaviour

In this process, Pending with the requestor also acts as the Initiator for the vendor creation workflow. After the vendor submits the request, the system automatically routes it to pending with requestor.

It has a contributor-style view where all information entered by both the initiator and the vendor is displayed in a read-only (disabled) form, and, based on this information, Requestor will enter the additional details specified below.
. Pending with the Accounts team behaviour
After the previous approver submits the request, the system automatically routes it to pending with account team based on the flow chart.

It has a contributor-style view where all information entered by previous stockholders is displayed in a read-only (disabled) form, and, based on this information, approver will enter the additional details specified below.

subsections.heading: 4.8 Communication Requirements
content: Effective communication is pivotal to the success of the vendor creation process. This section delineates the communication strategies, channels, templates, and protocols to ensure timely and accurate information dissemination among stakeholders.

subsections.heading: 4.8.1 Communication Channels
content: Identify and utilize appropriate channels for different types of communication.:
Email: For formal notifications, approvals, and escalations.

subsections.heading: 4.8.2 Communication Templates
content: Standardize messages to ensure consistency and professionalism:
Email Templates For Vendor
Subject: On behalf of Pidilite - Request to process the document | Title: Vendor Creation
Body : Dear  [Name of vendor],
Welcome to the Pidilite Vendor Onboarding Process. Click the {link} to access your account and continue with the application process.
Kindly ensure the following documents are submitted in PDF and JPEG format, with each file not exceeding 4 MB in size:
a)  GST Certificate – If registered/Applicable
b)  PAN Card – Mandatory
c)  Aadhaar Card – If applicable
d)  Bank Details / Cancelled Cheque – Mandatory (Alternatively, a Bank Authorization Letter is acceptable)
e)  MSME Certificate – If applicable
f)   CIN (Corporate Identification Number) – Mandatory if registered as a company
We appreciate your cooperation in providing these documents.
Note: This is a system-generated email. Please do not revert.
Thanks,
Team Pidilite
Email Templates For Approver
Subject: On behalf of Pidilite - Request to Approve the document | Title: Vendor Creation
Body: Please review the document in the following link and provide the approval
- Link
Please contact support@manchtech.com for further support.
Regards,
Team Pidilite.

subsections.heading: 4.11.3 Data Flow and Synchronization
content: Data Directionality:
Outbound: Data sent from the internal system to external systems.
Inbound: Data received from external systems into the internal system.
Synchronization Frequency:
Real-Time: Immediate data exchange upon event triggers.
Scheduled: Data exchange occurs at defined intervals (e.g., hourly, daily).
Conflict Resolution: Define rules for handling data discrepancies, such as prioritizing the most recent update or flagging for manual review.

spoc_fields.name: Please choose the option
spoc_fields.logic: Vendor will choose any one from the options and chosen option will be visible and mandatory: 1. Cancelled Cheque (India Domestic) 2. Passbook Front Page (India Domestic and International) 3. Cancelled Cheque (India Import and International) 4. SWIFT Image (India Import and International) 5. Bank Statement/Confirmation (India Import and International) Vendor will choose and upload any one option

spoc_fields.name: Cancelled Cheque Image
spoc_fields.logic: If process type is India and Please choose the option is choose as Cancelled Cheque then it is visible and mandatory. The upload limit should be up to 15 Mb. Perform the Bank OCR and get IFSC code and Account Number

spoc_fields.name: Passbook/Bank Letter
spoc_fields.logic: If Please the option is chosen as Passbook Front Page (India Domestic and International)then it is visible and mandatory. The upload limit should be up to 15 Mb.

spoc_fields.name: Please enter IFSC and Account Number manually
spoc_fields.logic: Show this fields if passbook front page (India Domestic and International) is selected

spoc_fields.name: IFSC Code
spoc_fields.logic: Non editable if cancelled cheque is selected. Editable for other option. Visible and mandatory for Cancelled Cheque (India Domestic) 2. Passbook Front Page (India Domestic and International). Otherwise invisible and non-mandatory. Auto-derived from OCR in case of cheque, manual entry in case of other options. Perform IFSC code verification

spoc_fields.name: Bank Account Number
spoc_fields.logic: Non editable if cancelled cheque is selected. Editable for other option. Visible and mandatory for Cancelled Cheque (India Domestic) 2. Passbook Front Page (India Domestic and International). Otherwise invisible and non-mandatory. Auto-derived from OCR in case of cheque, manual entry in case of other options ,Perform Bank account verification

spoc.description: The process will be initiated by the initiator by logging into the system and clicking on the create option in the dashboard.
This process can be initiated by any user in the system. The user should be active in the Pidilite HRMS system. This data will be maintained in the Manch EDV system.
Once the Vendor enters the details and clicks on submit. The system will perform the validation and send the details to the approvers for them to take action.

initiator.description: Login: The Pidilite team logs in to the Manch application using the provided credentials. The following basic details are shown to the user for each transaction created.
Company Name – Title (Copy the company name FFD Data into Title)
Vendor Code – Attribute 1 (Copt the vendor code FFD Data into Attribute 1)
Create By – Show the created by email id
Status – Display the external status with next approver and rejection details (when applicable)
Initiation: The user will click on the create option and select the vendor creation process.
Form will open with the below details of initiator. Initiator will be able to view only Basic details panel and fields as mentioned below. All the fields will be having common logic with them.
Once the Initiator enters the details and clicks on submit. The system will perform the validation and send the details to the vendor for them to take action.

approver.description: For India, the workflow will consist of six sequential approval levels:
Pending with Requestor – Initial review and confirmation by the requestor.
Pending with Vertical Head – Review and approval by the relevant business/vertical head.
Pending with Functional Head – Review and approval by the applicable functional head (e.g., Finance, Operations).
Pending with Accounts Team – Validation of accounting and finance-related information.
Pending with Auditor – Compliance and audit validation as required.

Pending with MDC Team – Final review by the MDC team. The MDC team can add ad hoc approvers as needed, up to a maximum of five parallel approvers. All ad hoc approvers must record their decisions, after which the request returns to the MDC approver, who then takes the final action in line with the defined common behaviour.
For Non-India, the workflow will consist of four sequential approval levels:
Pending with Requestor – Initial review and confirmation by the requestor. It is a contributor.
Pending with Country Head – Review and approval by the respective country head.
Pending with Auditor – Compliance and audit validation as required.

Pending with MDC Team – Final review by the MDC team. The MDC team can add ad hoc approvers as needed, up to a maximum of five parallel approvers. All ad hoc approvers must record their decisions, after which the request returns to the MDC approver, who then takes the final action in line with the defined common behaviour.

In this process, Pending with the requestor also acts as the Initiator for the vendor creation workflow. After the vendor submits the request, the system automatically routes it to pending with requestor.

It has a contributor-style view where all information entered by both the initiator and the vendor is displayed in a read-only (disabled) form, and, based on this information, Requestor will enter the additional details specified below.
After the previous approver submits the request, the system automatically routes it to pending with account team based on the flow chart.

It has a contributor-style view where all information entered by previous stockholders is displayed in a read-only (disabled) form, and, based on this information, approver will enter the additional details specified below.

scope_in: Capture and validation of vendor master data through a standardized vendor creation form (internal and external-facing).
Workflow for vendor request initiation, review, and approval, and compliance as applicable.
Storage and verification of mandatory supporting documents (e.g., tax, banking, registration, and compliance certificates).
Creation and update of vendor records in the target ERP/procurement system, including basic integration or interface design.
Basic reporting and dashboards for tracking vendor requests, status and turnaround times.
scope_out: Advanced vendor performance management, risk scoring, and contract lifecycle management functionalities.
Decommissioning or redesign of unrelated procurement processes (e.g., purchase requisition, purchase order, or invoicing flows).
